Chief Complaint: Cardiac arrest, bradycardia, seizure, acute
   respiartory failure
   I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /
   her note above, including assessment and plan.
   HPI:
   80 year old man with hx of CAD. Lives in nursing home. Was observed to
   have seizure yesterday. Given ativan at the nursing home; was post
   ictal for 10 mins and question of left sided weakness. Admitted to
   neuro. Head CT negative. Electroytes were normal.
   Early this AM, paitent had cardiac arrest. Nursing did chest
   compression for one minute; HR reportedly 30. First blood pressure
   noted by physicians was 150 systolic and he had sinus brady with HR
   40-50. Patient intubated for agonal breathing. Was given atropine with
   improved HR. Transferred to MICU where BP has been stable with good O2
   sats.
   ABG 7.23/70/151 with lactate 8.6 during arrest (pre-intubation). Later
   this morning, ABG:  7.45/45/191 on 50% oxygen with lactate < 2.
   24 Hour Events:
   Past Hx:
   CAD
   Hypertension
   COPD
   ostoporosis
   prpstate hypertrophy
   demenstia
   SH: < 1ppd X 50 years; EtoH: social

   Bili:40/0.6, Differential-Neuts:32.8 %, Band:0.0 %, Lymph:61.1 %,
   Mono:4.9 %, Eos:0.9 %, Lactic Acid:0.9 mmol/L, Ca++:8.2 mg/dL, Mg++:1.7
   mg/dL, PO4:3.2 mg/dL
   ECG: ECG: NSR. ST scooping I, AVL with T wave inversion V5-V6. Possible
   old IMI. No old ECG for comparison.
   CXR: no effusions or infiltates.
   Assessment and Plan
   CARDIAC ARREST
   ACUTE RESPIRATORY FAIULRE
   ANEMIA
   SEIZURE
   BARDYCADIA
   =================
   Patient with apparent bradycardic arrest; at worst pulse/BP absent for
   1 minute or less. Cause of arrest unclear, but vagal stimulus a
   consideration. Patient remains relatively bradycardic now, however,
   suggesting sinus nodal disease. Inferior ischemia also a consideration
   in light of ECG with possible old IMI. Patient has been on atenolol at
   the nursing home; possible that he received too much medication.
   Intracranial hypertension may cause bradycardia/hypertension, but CT
   was negative on admission. Deviation of eyes now suggest possible
   stroke. Would consider MRI/MRA. Patient also due for EEG. Obtain
   cardiac enzymes. Metabolic acidosis at time of arrest may be more
   indicative of seizure at the beginning of the arrest given that patient
   was not hyptensive for very long. Place transcutaneous pacer pads.
   Replete potassium.
   Patient somewhat hypertensive now. [**Month (only) 8**] be related to agitation. Will
   switch ventilator to PSV from assit control. If BP remains elevated,
   consider adding back his ACE inhibitor. Target BP would be 140-160
   sytolic. Avoid hypotension with possible CVA. [**Month (only) 8**] be able to extubate
   post MRI.
   Hct is down consistent with prior hx of anemia. No evidence of blood
   loss. Not at transfusion threshold.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: NPO
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2122-7-23**] 03:56 AM
   Arterial Line - [**2122-7-23**] 04:00 AM
   Multi Lumen - [**2122-7-23**] 05:13 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Comments:
   Communication: Patient discussed on interdisciplinary rounds , ICU
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition :ICU
   Total time spent: 45 minutes
   Patient is critically ill

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old man with a history of CAD, hypertension, COPD, osteoporosis, prostate hypertrophy, and dementia. He was admitted to the ICU after experiencing cardiac arrest, bradycardia, and a seizure. He was found to have a lactate level of 8.6 during the arrest, which suggests severe tissue hypoperfusion. He was intubated and received atropine to improve his heart rate. His blood pressure has been stable since being transferred to the MICU, with good oxygen saturation.

The patient has a history of anemia, and his Hct is currently low, but not at the transfusion threshold. He has a possible old MI on his ECG, and his CXR is normal. He is currently receiving midazolam, a sedative, and is unable to provide a history due to being intubated.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest may have been caused by a variety of factors, including vagal stimulation, sinus nodal disease, or inferior ischemia. He remains at risk for further cardiac arrest if his underlying condition is not addressed.
2. Bradycardia: The patient's bradycardia may be a result of his cardiac arrest or may be a separate condition. He may be at risk for further bradycardia or asystole if his sinus nodal disease is not managed.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be a result of his underlying condition or may be caused by bleeding or blood loss. He may be at risk for further anemia if his anemia is not addressed.
4. Seizure: The patient's seizure may have been caused by a variety of factors, including electrolyte imbalances, infection, or underlying medical conditions. He may be at risk for further seizures if his underlying condition is not addressed.
5. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may be a result of his cardiac arrest or may be a separate condition. He may be at risk for further metabolic acidosis if his underlying condition is not addressed.
6. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension may be a result of his cardiac arrest or may be a separate condition. He may be at risk for further hypertension if his underlying condition is not addressed.
7. Stroke: The patient's deviation of eyes may suggest a possible stroke. He may be at risk for further stroke if his underlying condition is not addressed.
8. Infection: The patient may be at risk for infection due to his intubation and his underlying condition.
9. Pneumonia: The patient may be at risk for pneumonia due to his intubation and his underlying condition.
10. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for VAP due to his intubation and his underlying condition.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust his medications as necessary.
2. Consider performing an MRI/MRA to rule out a stroke.
3. Obtain cardiac enzymes to rule out an MI.
4. Replete potassium to prevent further cardiac arrhythmias.
5. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust his medications as necessary.
6. Consider adding back his ACE inhibitor if his blood pressure remains elevated.
7. Avoid hypotension with possible CVA.
8. Consider extubating the patient post-MRI if he is able to breathe spontaneously.
9. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusing if necessary.
10. Monitor the patient's seizure activity and consider adjusting his medications as necessary.

TEXT:
Chief Complaint: The patient is a 80y/o M with a PMH of CAD, HTN, PVD,
   COPD admitted to neurology service for new onset seizure now
   transferred to MICU following bradycardic arrest. Per admission note,
   the patient lives at a NH and was found to have leftward eye deviation
   after eating breakfast this am, followed by generalized tonic-clonic
   activity. Unclear duration of symptoms. He was given 1mg Ativan, was
   noted to have incontinence of bowel and bladder, however this is his
   baseline. Reported to be post-ictal for approx 10 minutes with minimal
   verbal output. There was question of L sided weakness at this time.
   There is no previous history of seizure.
   .
   He was admitted to neurology service with preliminary workup including
   Head CT negative. On the evening of transfer, Code Blue was called at
   approx. 2am for asystole. Chest compressions were briefly administered
   (~1min) prior to code team arrival. Per report the patient had
   bradycardia followed by asystole with spontaneous return of
   circulation. The patient was intubated for agonal breathing. 2PIV and L
   femoral line were placed. He received 2mg ativan without response. The
   patient was given 1mg atropine for bradycardia to rate of the 30s with
   improvement in HR to 70s. BP stable throughout. ECG without ischemic
   changes. He is now transferred to the MICU for further management.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of CAD, HTN, PVD, and COPD, admitted to the neurology service for a new onset seizure. He was found to have leftward eye deviation and generalized tonic-clonic activity after eating breakfast, and was given 1mg of Ativan. The patient was intubated after a bradycardic arrest and asystole, and was transferred to the MICU for further management.

The patient has a history of dementia, including Alzheimer's and multi-infarct dementia. He has been treated with Midazolam (Versed) at a rate of 1mg/hour. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 54bpm, blood pressure of 187/67mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. His respiratory support includes invasive ventilation, arterial line, and multi-lumen catheter.

Physical examination reveals pinpoint pupils, upward deviation of the eyes, and a hyperdynamic cardiovascular system. The patient's abdomen is soft and non-tender, with bowel sounds present. His extremities show right lower extremity edema, and his skin is warm.

Laboratory results include:

* Serum sodium: 137 mEq/L
* Serum potassium: 4.1 mEq/L
* Serum creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 27 mEq/L
* Glucose: 129 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.2 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.7 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 3.2 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L
* Troponin-T: 72 ng/mL
* CK/CKMB: 72 ng/mL
* ALT/AST: 8-20 IU/L
* Alkaline phosphatase/T bilirubin: 40/0.6 IU/L
* Differential count: 32.8% neutrophils, 0.0% bands, 61.1% lymphocytes, 4.9% monocytes, 0.9% eosinophils

Potential medical complications:

* Status epilepticus
* Bradycardia
* Asystole
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrest
* Hypotension
* Hypoxia
* Hypercapnia
* Pneumonia
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
* Stress ulcer
* Seizure-related complications (e.g. aspiration, injury)
* Neurological complications (e.g. cerebral edema, intracranial hemorrhage)

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment & Plan:  80y/o M with a PMH of CAD, HTN, PVD, COPD admitted
   to neurology service for new onset seizure now transferred to MICU
   following bradycardic arrest.
   .
   # Bradycardia - Pt had evidence of sinus bradycardia prior to becoming
   hypotensive. Currently with HR 40-50. No clear evidence of ischemia.
   Could consider additional causes of bradycardia including neurologic,
   sick sinus syndrome, metabolic (lytes currently WNL), medication
   overdose (atenolol).
   - Trend CE
   - Repeat ECG in am
   - Hold atenolol
   - Check TTE
   - Head imaging with MRI in am
   .
   # Seizure - Per neurology concern given for complex partial seizure
   with secondary generalization and subsequent mild [**Doctor Last Name 6180**] paralysis on
   admission. Pt was not on monitoring so it is unclear if seizure was an
   inciting event code blue
   - EEG in am
   - Head MRI/MRA in am
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - continue midazolam for sedation
   .
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure - PCO2 70 in the setting of
   bradycardia, low respiratory rate. Now resolved.
   - Will transition to PSV, RSBI in am
   - If MRI scheduled for early am, plan to extubate following imaging
   study
   .
   # CAD - unclear history of CAD
   - CE neg [**Name (NI) 4918**]
   - Repeat ECG in am
   - Obtain TTE
   .
   # COPD - Per report Pt has a history of COPD, had evidence of CO2
   retention during Code blue event however this was most likely secondary
   to decreased respiratory rate in setting of seizure vs bradycardic
   event
   .
   # FEN - NPO for now, replete K to 4 and Mg to 2
   .
   # Access - L femoral line (placed in Code) 3PIV
   .
   # Code - Full
   .
   # Dispo - Pending above
   ICU Care

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Status Epilepticus: The patient has had a seizure and is at risk for further seizures, which can lead to status epilepticus, a life-threatening condition.
2. Bradycardia: The patient's heart rate is currently 40-50 beats per minute, which is considered bradycardic. This can lead to decreased cardiac output, decreased blood pressure, and potentially life-threatening arrhythmias.
3. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient had a PCO2 of 70, indicating hypercarbic respiratory failure. This can lead to respiratory acidosis, which can further exacerbate the patient's condition.
4. Cardiac Arrest: The patient had a code blue event and was resuscitated. This increases the risk of cardiac arrest recurring.
5. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and has a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, which is lower than normal. This increases the risk of respiratory failure.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient has a history of dementia, including Alzheimer's disease and multi-infarct dementia, which increases the risk of neurological complications such as seizures, stroke, and cognitive decline.
7. Infection: The patient has a history of COPD and is at risk for respiratory infections, which can further exacerbate their condition.
8. Sepsis: The patient has a history of PVD and is at risk for sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ failure.
9. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient has a history of constipation and is at risk for gastrointestinal complications such as bowel obstruction, perforation, and bleeding.
10. Medication-Related Complications: The patient is taking multiple medications, including anticoagulants, antiplatelet agents, and sedatives, which can increase the risk of medication-related complications such as bleeding, thrombosis, and sedation.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of lactate, which can indicate tissue hypoxia and increase the risk of multi-organ failure. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, but the patient's potassium level is slightly elevated, which can increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias.

The patient's imaging studies show evidence of lung consolidation and pleural effusion, which can indicate pneumonia or pleurisy. The patient's cardiac enzymes are elevated, which can indicate myocardial infarction or injury.

The patient's management plan includes continued monitoring of their vital signs, respiratory status, and neurological function. The patient will also receive antibiotics for suspected pneumonia and will be treated for bradycardia and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient's family should be informed of the patient's condition and the potential risks and complications associated with their treatment.

TEXT:
Chief Complaint: The patient is a 80y/o M with a PMH of CAD, HTN, PVD,
   COPD admitted to neurology service for new onset seizure now
   transferred to MICU following bradycardic arrest. Per admission note,
   the patient lives at a NH and was found to have leftward eye deviation
   after eating breakfast this am, followed by generalized tonic-clonic
   activity. Unclear duration of symptoms. He was given 1mg Ativan, was
   noted to have incontinence of bowel and bladder, however this is his
   baseline. Reported to be post-ictal for approx 10 minutes with minimal
   verbal output. There was question of L sided weakness at this time.
   There is no previous history of seizure.
   .
   He was admitted to neurology service with preliminary workup including
   Head CT negative. On the evening of transfer, Code Blue was called at
   approx. 2am for asystole. Chest compressions were briefly administered
   (~1min) prior to code team arrival. Per report the patient had
   bradycardia followed by asystole with spontaneous return of
   circulation. The patient was intubated for agonal breathing. 2PIV and L
   femoral line were placed. He received 2mg ativan without response. The
   patient was given 1mg atropine for bradycardia to rate of the 30s with
   improvement in HR to 70s. BP stable throughout. ECG without ischemic
   changes. He is now transferred to the MICU for further management.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of CAD, HTN, PVD, COPD, and dementia, admitted to the neurology service for a new onset seizure. He was found to have leftward eye deviation and generalized tonic-clonic activity after eating breakfast. He was given 1mg of Ativan and was noted to have incontinence of bowel and bladder, which is his baseline. The patient was transferred to the MICU following a bradycardic arrest and was intubated for agonal breathing. He received 2mg of Ativan without response and was given 1mg of atropine for bradycardia, which improved his heart rate to the 70s.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 54 bpm, blood pressure of 187/67 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. His respiratory support includes invasive ventilation, and his laboratory results show an elevated blood glucose level of 129 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Status epilepticus: The patient's history of seizure and the presence of generalized tonic-clonic activity suggest a high risk of status epilepticus.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's requirement for invasive ventilation and the presence of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) increase the risk of respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of bradycardic arrest and the presence of coronary artery disease (CAD) increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
4. Sepsis: The patient's elevated blood glucose level and the presence of chronic diseases such as diabetes and hypertension increase the risk of sepsis.
5. Dementia: The patient's history of dementia and the presence of chronic diseases such as Alzheimer's disease and multi-infarct dementia increase the risk of cognitive decline and behavioral disturbances.
6. Pressure ulcers: The patient's history of bedridden status and the presence of chronic diseases such as diabetes and hypertension increase the risk of pressure ulcers.
7. Infection: The patient's history of chronic diseases such as COPD and the presence of invasive devices such as arterial lines and central lines increase the risk of infection.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of chronic diseases such as gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and the presence of anticoagulant therapy increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and respiratory and cardiac status to prevent and manage these potential complications.

   activity. Unclear duration of symptoms. He was given 1mg Ativan, was

   femoral line were placed. He received 2mg ativan without response. The

   improvement in HR to 70s. BP stable throughout. ECG without ischemic
   changes. He is now transferred to the MICU for further management.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of CAD, HTN, PVD, and COPD, who was admitted to the neurology service for new onset seizure. He was found to have leftward eye deviation and generalized tonic-clonic activity after eating breakfast. He was given Ativan, but did not respond. The patient was transferred to the MICU following a bradycardic arrest, during which he had asystole and required chest compressions. He was intubated for agonal breathing and received Atropine for bradycardia. The patient has a history of seizure disorder, but this is his first reported seizure. He is currently on multiple medications, including anticonvulsants, antihypertensives, and anticholinergics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Status Epilepticus: The patient is at risk for further seizures due to his history of seizure disorder and the presence of underlying medical conditions such as CAD, HTN, and PVD.
2. Bradycardia: The patient's bradycardic arrest and requirement for Atropine suggest a risk for further bradycardic episodes, which could lead to cardiac arrest.
3. Hypoglycemia: The patient's history of taking medications that can cause hypoglycemia (e.g. anticholinergics) and his recent seizure activity increase his risk for hypoglycemia.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's need for intubation and mechanical ventilation increases his risk for respiratory failure, particularly if his underlying COPD is not well-managed.
5. Infection: The patient's recent transfer to the MICU and his underlying medical conditions increase his risk for infection, particularly pneumonia or urinary tract infections.
6. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and his underlying CAD, HTN, and PVD increase his risk for further cardiac arrests.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's recent seizure activity and his history of dementia increase his risk for further neurological complications, such as stroke or encephalopathy.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of taking medications that can cause gastrointestinal side effects (e.g. anticholinergics) and his recent seizure activity increase his risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as constipation or diarrhea.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with a complex medical history, including CAD, HTN, PVD, and COPD, who was admitted to the neurology service for a new onset seizure. The patient's condition has rapidly deteriorated, with a bradycardic arrest and subsequent asystole, requiring chest compressions and intubation. He was transferred to the MICU for further management.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: Intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a stable SpO2 of 100%.
* Cardiovascular: Bradycardia with a rate of 54 bpm, which improved with 1mg of atropine to a rate of 70s. Blood pressure is stable at 187/67 mmHg.
* Neurological: The patient is post-ictal, with minimal verbal output, and has no previous history of seizure. There is a question of left-sided weakness.
* Renal: The patient has a creatinine level of 0.7 mg/dL, which is slightly elevated.
* Hepatic: The patient has mildly elevated liver enzymes, including ALT and AST.
* Electrolytes: The patient has mild hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Seizure recurrence: Given the patient's history of seizure and the presence of status epilepticus, there is a high risk of seizure recurrence.
* Respiratory complications: The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, which increases the risk of respiratory complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's bradycardic arrest and asystole increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
* Renal complications: The patient's slightly elevated creatinine level increases the risk of acute kidney injury (AKI).
* Neurological complications: The patient's post-ictal state and potential left-sided weakness increase the risk of neurological complications such as stroke or intracranial hemorrhage.

The patient requires close monitoring and management in the MICU to prevent and address these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment & Plan:  80y/o M with a PMH of CAD, HTN, PVD, COPD admitted
   to neurology service for new onset seizure now transferred to MICU
   following bradycardic arrest.
   .
   # Bradycardia - Pt had evidence of sinus bradycardia prior to becoming
   hypotensive. Currently with HR 40-50. No clear evidence of ischemia.
   Could consider additional causes of bradycardia including
   hypothyroidism (TSH 6.3)***, neurologic (such as ICP), associated with
   increased vagal tone, heightened parasympathetic, withdrawal sympa as
   with valsalva, micturition, cough, sick sinus syndrome, metabolic in
   particular K+ (lytes currently WNL), medication overdose (atenolol),
   donepezil.  Lactic acidosis to 8.6 resolved this am, perhaps during
   hypotension, may have underlying subclinical brady/hypotension, finally
   resulting in this episode. No leukocytosis, fever to invoke infection.
   - Trended CE: 1^st set 0.01 and no EKG changes
   - Repeat ECG this morning is unchanged.
   - Hold atenolol
   - Check TTE
   - Head imaging with MRI in am
   .
   # Seizure - Per neurology concern given for complex partial seizure
   with secondary generalization and subsequent mild [**Doctor Last Name 6180**] paralysis on
   admission. Pt was not on monitoring so it is unclear if seizure was an
   inciting event code blue
   - EEG in am
   - Head MRI/MRA in am
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - continue midazolam for sedation
   .
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure - PCO2 70 in the setting of
   bradycardia, low respiratory rate. Now resolved with gas this am of
   7.45, PCO2 of 45 from 7.23/70.
   -CXR y/d showed ? atelectasis vs fluid in fissure
   - Will transition to PSV, check  RSBI in am.
   - If MRI scheduled for early am, plan to extubate following imaging
   study.
   .
   # CAD - unclear history of CAD
   - CE neg [**Name (NI) 4918**]
   - Repeat ECG in am
   - Obtain TTE
   .
   # COPD - Per report Pt has a history of COPD, had evidence of CO2
   retention during Code blue event however this was most likely secondary
   to decreased respiratory rate in setting of seizure vs bradycardic
   event
   .
   # FEN - NPO for now, replete K to 4 and Mg to 2
   .
   # Access - L femoral line (placed in Code) 3PIV
   .
   # Code - Full
   .

Chief Complaint: The patient is a 80y/o M with a PMH of CAD, HTN, PVD,
   COPD admitted to neurology service for new onset seizure now
   transferred to MICU following bradycardic arrest. Per admission note,
   the patient lives at a NH and was found to have leftward eye deviation
   after eating breakfast this am, followed by generalized tonic-clonic
   activity. Unclear duration of symptoms. He was given 1mg Ativan, was
   noted to have incontinence of bowel and bladder, however this is his
   baseline. Reported to be post-ictal for approx 10 minutes with minimal
   verbal output. There was question of L sided weakness at this time.
   There is no previous history of seizure.
   .
   He was admitted to neurology service with preliminary workup including
   Head CT negative. On the evening of transfer, Code Blue was called at
   approx. 2am for asystole. Chest compressions were briefly administered
   (~1min) prior to code team arrival. Per report the patient had
   bradycardia followed by asystole with spontaneous return of
   circulation. The patient was intubated for agonal breathing. 2PIV and L
   femoral line were placed. He received 2mg ativan without response. The
   patient was given 1mg atropine for bradycardia to rate of the 30s with
   improvement in HR to 70s. BP stable throughout. ECG without ischemic
   changes. He is now transferred to the MICU for further management.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with a past medical history of CAD, HTN, PVD, COPD, and dementia, admitted to the neurology service for a new onset seizure. The patient was transferred to the MICU following a bradycardic arrest.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and the oxygen saturation is 100%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has a heart rate of 54 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 187/67 mmHg. The patient has a history of CAD, but the current ECG is unchanged.
* Neurological status: The patient had a seizure, which was not on monitoring, and it is unclear if the seizure was an inciting event for the code blue. The patient has a history of dementia, and the current neurological examination is unchanged.
* Laboratory results: The patient's laboratory results show an elevated troponin level, but the cause is unclear. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, but there is a risk of respiratory failure due to the patient's COPD and the possibility of a respiratory infection.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient has a history of CAD and has had a bradycardic arrest, which increases the risk of cardiovascular instability.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient has a history of dementia and has had a seizure, which increases the risk of neurological deterioration.
* Infection: The patient has a history of COPD and is intubated, which increases the risk of infection.
* Hypotension: The patient has a history of PVD and has had a bradycardic arrest, which increases the risk of hypotension.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following plan of care should be implemented:

* Continue mechanical ventilation and monitoring of the patient's respiratory status.
* Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust treatment as necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust treatment as necessary.
* Consider performing a head CT or MRI to rule out any structural abnormalities that may be contributing to the patient's condition.
* Consider performing an EEG to rule out any seizure activity.
* Consider adjusting the patient's medication regimen to address any underlying conditions that may be contributing to the patient's condition.
* Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust treatment as necessary.
* Consider performing a stress test to rule out any cardiac issues.
* Consider performing a pulmonary function test to rule out any respiratory issues.

Chief Complaint: The patient is a 80y/o M with a PMH of CAD, HTN, PVD,
   COPD admitted to neurology service for new onset seizure now
   transferred to MICU following bradycardic arrest. Per admission note,
   the patient lives at a NH and was found to have leftward eye deviation
   after eating breakfast this am, followed by generalized tonic-clonic
   activity. Unclear duration of symptoms. He was given 1mg Ativan, was
   noted to have incontinence of bowel and bladder, however this is his
   baseline. Reported to be post-ictal for approx 10 minutes with minimal
   verbal output. There was question of L sided weakness at this time.
   There is no previous history of seizure.
   .
   He was admitted to neurology service with preliminary workup including
   Head CT negative. On the evening of transfer, Code Blue was called at
   approx. 2am for asystole. Chest compressions were briefly administered
   (~1min) prior to code team arrival. Per report the patient had
   bradycardia followed by asystole with spontaneous return of
   circulation. The patient was intubated for agonal breathing. 2PIV and L
   femoral line were placed. He received 2mg ativan without response. The
   patient was given 1mg atropine for bradycardia to rate of the 30s with
   improvement in HR to 70s. BP stable throughout. ECG without ischemic
   changes. He is now transferred to the MICU for further management.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with a past medical history of CAD, HTN, PVD, and COPD, who was admitted to the neurology service for a new onset seizure. The patient had a bradycardic arrest during the night, which was treated with chest compressions and atropine. He was intubated for agonal breathing and was transferred to the MICU for further management.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 37C (98.6F), HR 54 bpm, BP 187/67 mmHg, RR 14 breaths/min, SpO2 100%
* Respiratory support: Intubated and ventilated with a CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow mode, FiO2 40%
* Cardiovascular: Bradycardia with a HR of 40-50 bpm, no clear evidence of ischemia
* Neurological: Right toe upgoing, no clear evidence of seizure activity
* Laboratory results: Normal WBC count, mild anemia, and elevated liver enzymes

The patient's potential medical complications are:

1. Status epilepticus: The patient had a seizure and was treated with ativan, but the seizure activity has not been fully controlled. The patient may require further treatment with anticonvulsants or sedatives to control the seizure activity.
2. Bradycardia: The patient's HR is 40-50 bpm, which is below normal. The patient may require further treatment with atropine or other medications to increase the HR.
3. Hypotension: The patient's BP is 187/67 mmHg, which is below normal. The patient may require further treatment with vasopressors or other medications to increase the BP.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and ventilated, but the patient's respiratory status may require further management to ensure adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
5. Sepsis: The patient's WBC count is normal, but the patient's temperature is not elevated, which may indicate the presence of sepsis.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's ECG is normal, but the patient's HR is below normal, which may indicate the presence of cardiac arrhythmias.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is uncertain, and the patient may require further evaluation with imaging studies or electroencephalograms to determine the presence of any neurological complications.

The patient's plan of care is as follows:

1. Continue midazolam for sedation and seizure control
2. Hold atenolol due to bradycardia
3. Obtain TTE to evaluate cardiac function
4. Perform head imaging with MRI to evaluate for any structural abnormalities
5. Continue respiratory support with a CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow mode
6. Monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust treatment as necessary
7. Consider additional treatments such as anticonvulsants or sedatives to control seizure activity.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of CAD, HTN, PVD, and COPD who was admitted to the neurology service for a new onset seizure. He was found to have leftward eye deviation and generalized tonic-clonic activity, with no previous history of seizure. The patient was given 1mg Ativan, but did not respond. He was intubated for agonal breathing and received 1mg atropine for bradycardia. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 54 bpm, blood pressure of 187/67 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. He is receiving mechanical ventilation and has a tracheostomy tube in place.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Seizure recurrence: The patient's seizure was not fully controlled, and there is a risk of recurrence. Monitoring for seizure activity and adjusting medication as necessary is crucial.
2. Status epilepticus: The patient's prolonged seizure activity may have led to status epilepticus, which is a life-threatening condition. Close monitoring for signs of status epilepticus, such as decreased responsiveness, increased muscle tone, and abnormal breathing, is essential.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's bradycardia and asystole may indicate underlying cardiac issues. Monitoring for cardiac arrhythmias and adjusting medication as necessary is crucial to prevent cardiac complications.
4. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but close monitoring for signs of respiratory distress, such as increased respiratory rate, decreased oxygen saturation, and increased peak airway pressure, is essential.
5. Infection: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and use of invasive lines and tubes increase the risk of infection. Monitoring for signs of infection, such as fever, leukocytosis, and increased inflammation markers, is crucial.
6. Nutritional complications: The patient's prolonged hospitalization may lead to malnutrition, which can exacerbate underlying medical conditions. Monitoring for signs of malnutrition, such as decreased appetite, weight loss, and decreased muscle mass, is essential.
7. Medication side effects: The patient is receiving multiple medications, including midazolam, atropine, and antibiotics. Monitoring for medication side effects, such as respiratory depression, sedation, and allergic reactions, is crucial.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, including seizure recurrence, status epilepticus, cardiac complications, respiratory complications, infection, nutritional complications, and medication side effects. Close monitoring and adjusting medication as necessary are crucial to prevent these complications and ensure the patient's optimal outcome.

   Patient with hypotension without evidence of aortic dissection. On exam
   has warm extremities with good capillary refill, which argues against
   low intravascular volume or cardiogenic shock. With fluids, BP now 110
   systolic and urine output improving. CVP now 20. Suspect that increase
   in antihypertensives may also have contributed to his low BP. WBC
   normal and patient afebrile with no apparent source of infection. ECG
   without evidence of acute ischemia. With elevated CVP and hypoxemia,
   would now begin to diurese gently. Patient has hardware in his back.
   Possibility of occult infection with nightsweats. Would obtain blood
   cultures but hold antibiotics for now.
   Acute renal failure worrisome for ATN with low BP. The amount of rise
   in creat from baseline suggests this process has been ongoing for
   several days. Urine Na, however, is low suggesting pre-renal azotemia.
   Monitor with improved volume status. Complete bicarb protocol for
   contrast he received.
   Elevated serum potassium probably related to acidosis and low urine
   output. Improving with volume resuscitation. Acidosis has anion gap
   probably related to renal failure.
   Hct down slightly from [**Month (only) 8**]. No evidence of bleeding. Monitor stool
   guaiac. Not at transfusion threshold.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's chief complaints are bradycardia and hypotension. The patient has a history of seizure disorder, dementia, and hypertension.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 98.6F (37C)
* Heart rate: 54 bpm (sinus bradycardia)
* Blood pressure: 187/67 mmHg (110 systolic) with improvement to 110 systolic after fluid resuscitation
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated creatinine level (1.29 mg/dL) with a rise from baseline, suggesting acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Low urine sodium level, indicating pre-renal azotemia
* Elevated serum potassium level (4.9 mEq/L) likely related to acidosis and low urine output
* Anion gap acidosis likely related to renal failure
* Low hemoglobin level ( Month 8) with no evidence of bleeding

The patient has the following hardware:

* Invasive ventilation
* Arterial line
* Multi-lumen catheter

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Hypotension without evidence of aortic dissection, possibly related to increase in antihypertensives
* Bradycardia
* Suspected occult infection with nightsweats
* Acute renal failure worrisome for ATN with low BP
* Elevated serum potassium likely related to acidosis and low urine output
* Improving with volume resuscitation
* Acidosis with anion gap likely related to renal failure
* Hct down slightly from Month 8 with no evidence of bleeding

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) secondary to hypotension and acute kidney injury
* Respiratory failure due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Sepsis or septic shock due to occult infection
* Cardiac arrest due to bradycardia and hypotension
* Worsening of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and potential need for dialysis
* Electrolyte imbalances, including hyperkalemia and acidosis
* Potential need for further cardiovascular support, such as vasopressors or inotropes.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with a history of seizure disorder, dementia, and bradycardia. They were admitted to the ICU due to hypotension and are currently receiving invasive ventilation, arterial line, and multi-lumen catheters. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 54 bpm and blood pressure of 110/67 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV ventilation with a set tidal volume of 500 mL and a spontaneous tidal volume of 347 mL. The patient's blood work reveals acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 1.29 mg/dL and an elevated serum potassium level of 4.9 mmol/L.

Assessment:

The patient's bradycardia and hypotension are likely related to their underlying medical conditions, including seizure disorder and dementia. The patient's acute renal failure is likely secondary to pre-renal azotemia, and their elevated serum potassium level is likely related to acidosis and low urine output. The patient's acidosis has anion gap, which suggests that it is related to renal failure.

Potential medical complications:

1. Worsening of acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is increasing, which suggests that their acute renal failure is worsening. This could lead to further complications, such as electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload.
2. Development of electrolyte imbalances: The patient's elevated serum potassium level could lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
3. Infection: The patient's history of nightsweats and the presence of hardware in their back suggest that they may be at risk for occult infection.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's bradycardia and hypotension could lead to cardiovascular instability, including cardiac arrest.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV ventilation, which could be inadequate to meet their oxygen demands. This could lead to respiratory failure.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of seizure disorder and dementia could lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as aspiration pneumonia or gastrointestinal bleeding.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with a chief complaint of bradycardia and hypotension. They have a history of seizure disorder, dementia, and are currently experiencing status epilepticus. They were admitted to the ICU for management of their respiratory failure and have been placed on invasive ventilation. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.6F, heart rate of 54 bpm, and blood pressure of 187/67 mmHg. They are receiving midazolam and fentanyl infusions, as well as other medications to manage their condition.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and they are at risk of developing further respiratory failure or complications such as pneumonia or respiratory acidosis.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient's bradycardia and hypotension put them at risk of cardiac arrest, especially if not managed promptly and effectively.
3. Seizure recurrence: The patient has a history of seizure disorder and is currently experiencing status epilepticus, which increases the risk of seizure recurrence.
4. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections, particularly pneumonia, due to their respiratory failure and the use of invasive ventilation.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient is at risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as stress ulceration or gastrointestinal bleeding, due to their critical illness.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's dementia and history of seizure disorder increase their risk of developing neurological complications, such as stroke or cerebral edema.
7. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hypotension and bradycardia increase their risk of hemodynamic instability, which can lead to organ failure or death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and respiratory status closely.
2. Adjust the patient's medications and treatment plan as necessary to manage their condition.
3. Consider consulting with a neurologist to further evaluate and manage the patient's seizure disorder.
4. Implement infection prevention measures, such as administering antibiotics and using central venous catheters with antimicrobial coating.
5. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status closely and consider administering prophylactic antacids or histamine-2 receptor antagonists.
6. Consider performing a head CT or MRI to further evaluate the patient's neurological status.
7. Continue to educate the patient's son about their condition and treatment plan.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with a chief complaint of bradycardia and hypotension. They have a history of seizure disorder, dementia, and are currently experiencing a new onset of tonic-clonic seizures. The patient is intubated and receiving invasive ventilation, and is also receiving multiple medications, including midazolam, fentanyl, and others. The patient's vital signs are stable, but they are experiencing relative bradycardia. The patient's physical examination is notable for cachexia, and their lab results show elevated levels of creatinine, potassium, and troponin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's bradycardia and hypotension may be indicative of a cardiac event, such as a myocardial infarction or cardiogenic shock. Further evaluation, including repeat ECG and echocardiogram, is necessary to rule out these possibilities.
2. Respiratory Complications: The patient's intubation and respiratory support may lead to complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or respiratory failure.
3. Neurological Complications: The patient's new onset of seizures and altered mental status may be indicative of a neurological event, such as a stroke or subarachnoid hemorrhage. Further evaluation, including neuroimaging and EEG, is necessary to rule out these possibilities.
4. Metabolic Complications: The patient's elevated levels of creatinine and potassium may be indicative of acute kidney injury or metabolic acidosis. Further evaluation, including electrolyte panel and urinalysis, is necessary to rule out these possibilities.
5. Infection Complications: The patient's presence in the ICU and receipt of invasive therapies, such as central lines and arterial lines, may increase their risk of infection. Further evaluation, including cultures and antimicrobial therapy, is necessary to rule out infection.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and cardiac rhythm closely.
2. Repeat ECG and echocardiogram to rule out cardiac complications.
3. Continue respiratory support and monitor for signs of respiratory failure.
4. Perform neuroimaging and EEG to rule out neurological complications.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte panel and urinalysis to rule out metabolic complications.
6. Continue to evaluate the patient for signs of infection and initiate antimicrobial therapy as necessary.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a [age]-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status, seizure, and respiratory failure. The patient underwent a trans-thoracic echo and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) which showed significant atrophy, no evidence of acute stroke, and no enhancement with contrast administration. The patient was extubated and is currently on a face tent with 40% oxygen. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8C, heart rate of 70 bpm, and blood pressure of 138/47 mmHg.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Seizure recurrence:** The patient has a history of seizure and is currently on anti-epileptic medication. There is a risk of seizure recurrence, especially if the medication is not effective or if the patient's electrolyte levels are not well-controlled.
2. **Respiratory failure:** The patient is currently on a face tent with 40% oxygen, which may not be sufficient to maintain adequate oxygenation. There is a risk of respiratory failure if the patient's oxygenation status deteriorates.
3. **Infection:** The patient has a central line and arterial line, which increases the risk of infection. There is a need for close monitoring of the patient's temperature and white blood cell count to detect any signs of infection early.
4. **Cardiovascular instability:** The patient's blood pressure is elevated, which may be a sign of cardiovascular instability. There is a risk of cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure if the patient's blood pressure is not well-controlled.
5. **Nutritional deficiencies:** The patient is NPO pending speech and swallow evaluation, which may lead to nutritional deficiencies if not addressed promptly.
6. **Cerebral edema:** The patient has significant atrophy on MRI, which may increase the risk of cerebral edema. There is a need for close monitoring of the patient's neurological status and head computed tomography (CT) scans to detect any signs of cerebral edema early.
7. **Hydrocephalus:** The patient's MRI shows ventriculomegaly, which may be consistent with normal pressure hydrocephalus. There is a risk of hydrocephalus if the patient's cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow is not adequate.
8. **Small vessel disease:** The patient's MRI shows extensive small vessel disease, which may increase the risk of stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA).

**Plan:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, neurological status, and laboratory results closely.
2. Adjust the patient's anti-epileptic medication as needed to prevent seizure recurrence.
3. Continue to provide respiratory support as needed to maintain adequate oxygenation.
4. Monitor the patient's central line and arterial line for signs of infection and maintain strict asepsis.
5. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust medication as needed to prevent cardiovascular instability.
6. Provide nutritional support as soon as possible to prevent nutritional deficiencies.
7. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and consider repeat head CT scans to detect any signs of cerebral edema or hydrocephalus early.
8. Consider consulting with a neurosurgeon or neurologist to discuss the patient's small vessel disease and potential treatment options.

   Assessment & Plan:  80y/o M with a PMH of CAD, HTN, PVD, COPD admitted
   to neurology service for new onset seizure now transferred to MICU
   following bradycardic arrest.
   .
   # Bradycardia - Pt had evidence of sinus bradycardia prior to becoming
   hypotensive. Currently with HR 40-50. No clear evidence of ischemia.
   Could consider additional causes of bradycardia including
   hypothyroidism (TSH 6.3)***, neurologic (such as ICP), associated with
   increased vagal tone, heightened parasympathetic, withdrawal sympa as
   with valsalva, micturition, cough, sick sinus syndrome, metabolic in
   particular K+ (lytes currently WNL), medication overdose (atenolol),
   donepezil.  Lactic acidosis to 8.6 resolved this am, perhaps during
   hypotension, may have underlying subclinical brady/hypotension, finally
   resulting in this episode. No leukocytosis, fever to invoke infection.
   - Trended CE: 1^st set 0.01 and no EKG changes
   - Repeat ECG this morning is unchanged.
   - Hold atenolol
   - Check TTE
   - Head imaging with MRI in am
   .
   # Seizure - Per neurology concern given for complex partial seizure
   with secondary generalization and subsequent mild [**Doctor Last Name 6180**] paralysis on
   admission. Pt was not on monitoring so it is unclear if seizure was an
   inciting event code blue
   - EEG in am
   - Head MRI/MRA in am
   - appreciate neuro recs
   - continue midazolam for sedation
   .
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure - PCO2 70 in the setting of
   bradycardia, low respiratory rate. Now resolved with gas this am of
   7.45, PCO2 of 45 from 7.23/70.
   -CXR y/d showed ? atelectasis vs fluid in fissure
   - Will transition to PSV, check  RSBI in am.
   - If MRI scheduled for early am, plan to extubate following imaging
   study.
   .
   # CAD - unclear history of CAD
   - CE neg [**Name (NI) 4918**]
   - Repeat ECG in am
   - Obtain TTE
   .
   # COPD - Per report Pt has a history of COPD, had evidence of CO2
   retention during Code blue event however this was most likely secondary
   to decreased respiratory rate in setting of seizure vs bradycardic
   event
   .
   # FEN - NPO for now, replete K to 4 and Mg to 2
   .
   # Access - L femoral line (placed in Code) 3PIV
   .
   # Code - Full
   .
   # Dispo - Pending above

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male who was admitted to the neurology service for new onset seizure and later transferred to the MICU following a bradycardic arrest. The patient has a history of CAD, HTN, PVD, and COPD.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is extubated and receiving oxygen therapy via a face tent. He has a respiratory rate of 29 inspirations per minute and a PaO2 of 175.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a heart rate of 70 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 138/47 mmHg. He has a history of CAD and HTN.
* Neurological: The patient has a history of seizure and is currently receiving midazolam for sedation. He has a head MRI/MRA scheduled for the morning.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient is NPO and has a history of COPD.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine level is 0.7 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 11.7 mg/dL.
* Hematological: The patient's white blood cell count is 5.2 K/uL, and his platelet count is 102 K/uL.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* Creatine kinase (CK): 117 IU/L
* CK-MB: 5 IU/L
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.5 g/dL
* Calcium: 8.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.6 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Ventriculomegaly with dilatation of the temporal horns, which is likely due to atrophy in the presence of widening of the choroidal fissure.
* Extensive small vessel disease in the periventricular and subcortical white matter and pons.
* No evidence of acute infarct or enhancing mass lesion.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Bradycardia: The patient's heart rate is 70 beats per minute, which is below the normal range. This could be due to various causes, including hypothyroidism, neurologic disorders, medication overdose, or underlying subclinical bradycardia.
* Seizure: The patient has a history of seizure and is currently receiving midazolam for sedation. He is at risk for further seizures, especially if his seizure disorder is not well-controlled.
* Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's PaCO2 level is 70, which is above the normal range. This could be due to various causes, including respiratory muscle weakness, sleep apnea, or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
* CAD: The patient has a history of CAD, which puts him at risk for further cardiovascular events, including myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
* COPD: The patient has a history of COPD, which puts him at risk for further respiratory exacerbations, including bronchospasm or respiratory failure.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Bradycardia: The patient's bradycardia will be monitored, and additional causes will be investigated. He will be treated with atropine if necessary.
* Seizure: The patient will be monitored for further seizures, and his seizure disorder will be managed with anticonvulsant medications.
* Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's PaCO2 level will be monitored, and he will be treated with oxygen therapy and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) if necessary.
* CAD: The patient's CAD will be managed with medication and lifestyle changes.
* COPD: The patient's COPD will be managed with medication and oxygen therapy.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, including bradycardia, seizure, hypercarbic respiratory failure, CAD, and COPD. He will require close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of CAD, HTN, PVD, and COPD who was admitted to the neurology service for new onset seizure and subsequently transferred to the MICU following bradycardic arrest. He has been diagnosed with severe dCHF, and his MRI shows atrophy, degeneration, and possible normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). He has been experiencing hypoglycemia, low sodium, and hypercarbic respiratory failure. He was extubated without complications and is currently receiving sedation for agitation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Seizure activity: The patient has a history of seizures and is currently being treated with anti-epileptic medication. However, there is a risk of seizure activity recurring, especially if the medication is not effective or if the patient experiences hypoglycemia or other underlying conditions that can trigger seizures.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient has been experiencing hypercarbic respiratory failure, which can lead to respiratory acidosis and potentially life-threatening complications if not addressed promptly.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of CAD and is currently experiencing severe dCHF. This can lead to cardiac arrest, arrhythmias, and other cardiac complications if not managed properly.
4. Infection: The patient has a history of COPD and is at risk of developing pneumonia or other respiratory infections, especially given his recent code blue event and current respiratory failure.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient is currently NPO pending a swallow evaluation, which can lead to malnutrition and dehydration if not managed properly.
6. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of dementia and is at risk of developing further neurological complications, such as stroke or brain hemorrhage, given his age and underlying medical conditions.
7. Medication-related complications: The patient is receiving multiple medications, including sedatives, anti-epileptic medication, and cardiac medications, which can interact with each other and increase the risk of adverse effects.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's seizure activity and adjust medication as needed to prevent further seizures.
2. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation as needed.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and adjust medication as needed to prevent cardiac complications.
4. Consider antibiotic therapy if the patient develops signs of infection.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust diet and hydration as needed to prevent malnutrition and dehydration.
6. Consider further neurological evaluation, such as an EEG, to assess the patient's neurological status and potential for further complications.
7. Monitor the patient's medication regimen closely and adjust as needed to prevent medication-related complications.

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of bradycardic arrest. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6C, heart rate of 85 bpm, blood pressure of 179/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 33 inspirations per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient is receiving respiratory support with a face tent and standby ventilator mode.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 11.7 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 5.2 K/uL
* Platelet count: 102 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* Glucose: 129 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.5 g/dL
* LDH: 204 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.6 mg/dL

The patient's medical history and review of systems are unchanged from admission, except for the noted alterations in nutrition, respiratory failure, and bradycardia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxia and hypercapnia
* Bradycardia, which can lead to decreased cardiac output and potentially life-threatening arrhythmias
* Seizure, which can lead to brain damage and respiratory failure
* Dementia, which can lead to decreased cognitive function and increased risk of falls and other complications
* Stress ulcer, which can lead to gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can lead to pulmonary embolism and other complications

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual who experienced a bradycardic arrest and was admitted to the ICU. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6C, heart rate of 85 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 179/64 mmHg. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy and is on standby ventilation. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 188 mmHg and a partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 33 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 5.2 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 11.7 g/dL, and platelet count of 102 x 10^9/L. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) of 9-17 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) of 9-17 IU/L. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with a potassium level of 4.6 mmol/L and a sodium level of 136 mmol/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for dementia, including Alzheimer's disease and multi-infarct dementia. The patient's family history is significant for a seizure disorder.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but the patient's history of respiratory failure and the use of standby ventilation increase the risk of respiratory complications.
2. Infection: The patient's history of sepsis and the use of antibiotics increase the risk of infection.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of bradycardic arrest and the use of cardiac medications increase the risk of cardiac complications.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's history of seizure disorder and the use of sedatives increase the risk of neurological complications.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and the use of anticoagulants increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications.
6. Renal complications: The patient's history of kidney disease and the use of diuretics increase the risk of renal complications.
7. Metabolic complications: The patient's history of diabetes and the use of insulin increase the risk of metabolic complications.
8. Hematological complications: The patient's history of anemia and the use of blood transfusions increase the risk of hematological complications.
9. Surgical complications: The patient's history of surgery and the use of anesthesia increase the risk of surgical complications.
10. Psychiatric complications: The patient's history of dementia and the use of psychotropic medications increase the risk of psychiatric complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male admitted to the ICU for bradycardic arrest. The patient has a complex medical history, including a seizure disorder, hypertension, and dementia.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.6C (99.7F)
* Heart rate: 85 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 179/64 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 33 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 95%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient is receiving various medications, including anticonvulsants, antihypertensives, and anticoagulants.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 5.2 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 11.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 102 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.5 g/dL
* LDH: 204 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.6 mg/dL

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Alteration in nutrition: The patient is at risk for malnutrition due to his poor oral intake and need for total parenteral nutrition.
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS): The patient has acute respiratory failure, which is not related to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
* H/O seizure, with status epilepticus: The patient has a history of seizures, and he experienced status epilepticus during his admission.

* Bradycardia: The patient has bradycardia, which is being monitored and managed with medication.

* Seizure recurrence: The patient has a history of seizures, and he experienced status epilepticus during his admission. He is at risk for seizure recurrence.
* Dementia progression: The patient has dementia, which can progress and worsen his cognitive and functional abilities.
* Bradycardia: The patient has bradycardia, which can worsen if not managed properly.

Overall, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of bradycardic arrest. The patient's medical history includes dementia, including Alzheimer's and multi-infarct dementia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T = 37.6C, HR = 85 bpm, BP = 179/64 mmHg, RR = 33 inspirations per minute, SpO2 = 95%
* Respiratory support: Invasive ventilation was stopped, and the patient is currently on standby mode with a face tent and 40% FiO2
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient has a central venous catheter and an arterial line
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 1,165 mL of fluids and has lost 607 mL, resulting in a net loss of 558 mL
* Blood products: The patient has received a total of 1,165 mL of blood products and has lost 245 mL, resulting in a net loss of 920 mL
* Urine output: The patient has produced 1,165 mL of urine
* Laboratory results: The patient's WBC count is 5.2, Hct is 36.6, and Plt is 102. His Cr is 0.7, TropT is <0.01, and TCO2 is 31.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration
* Bradycardia: The patient's heart rate is slow, and there is a risk of cardiac arrest
* Sepsis: The patient's WBC count is elevated, and there is a risk of septicemia
* Fluid overload: The patient has received a large amount of fluids, and there is a risk of fluid overload and pulmonary edema
* Bleeding: The patient has received blood products, and there is a risk of bleeding and hematoma formation

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue respiratory support with invasive ventilation and non-invasive ventilation as needed
* Monitor the patient's heart rate and rhythm closely and consider cardioversion if necessary
* Monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust fluids accordingly to prevent fluid overload
* Monitor the patient's WBC count and consider antibiotics if there is evidence of sepsis
* Monitor the patient's bleeding status and consider transfusions if necessary
* Continue to monitor the patient's urine output and adjust fluids accordingly to prevent dehydration.

* The patient had a trans-thoracic echo and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) on July 23, 2022.
* The patient was intubated and placed on invasive ventilation until July 23, 2022, at 05:16 PM. They were then transitioned to a face tent with standby ventilation.
* The patient was given multiple medications, including antibiotics, antacids, and heparin sodium.
* The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 85 beats per minute, blood pressure of 179/64 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 33 breaths per minute.

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Cachetic appearance
* Pupils reactive
* Diminished breath sounds bilaterally with no wheezes
* Soft and non-tender abdomen
* Thin and wasted extremities with no edema or rash
* Alert and interactive but confused neurologically

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 11.7 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 5.2 K/uL
* Platelet count: 102 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* Albumin: 3.5 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Dementia (including Alzheimer's and multi-infarct)
* Bradycardia
* Hypoglycemia
* Seizure disorder (new onset)

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: continued difficulty clearing secretions and weaning off oxygen therapy
* Bradycardia: potential for further episodes of bradycardic arrest
* Hypoglycemia: potential for recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia
* Seizure disorder: potential for further seizures and complications related to seizure activity
* Dementia: potential for further cognitive decline and complications related to dementia
* Cardiovascular complications: potential for further cardiac arrhythmias and complications related to cardiac disease.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results
* Management of respiratory failure, including weaning off oxygen therapy and clearing secretions
* Management of bradycardia, including monitoring for further episodes of bradycardic arrest
* Management of hypoglycemia, including monitoring blood glucose levels and administering dextrose as needed
* Management of seizure disorder, including loading on IV Depakote and monitoring for further seizures
* Management of dementia, including monitoring for further cognitive decline and complications related to dementia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 65-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after a bradycardic arrest. The patient has a complex medical history, including a mood disorder, dementia, and a history of seizures.

Current vital signs:

* Temperature: 37.6C (99.7F)
* Heart rate: 85 bpm (normal range 60-100 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 179/64 mmHg (normal range 120/80 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 33 breaths per minute (normal range 12-20 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 95%
* Cardiac rhythm: sinus rhythm

The patient is receiving respiratory support with a face tent and is being weaned off the ventilator. He is also receiving IV antibiotics, anticonvulsants, and antihypertensive medications.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 5.2 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 11.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 102 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.5 g/dL
* LDH: 204 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.6 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE): normal
* Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): showed degenerative changes in the brain

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: the patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to his underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and his current respiratory status.
2. Seizure recurrence: the patient has a history of seizures and is currently being treated with anticonvulsants. He is at risk for seizure recurrence.
3. Hypoglycemia: the patient is at risk for hypoglycemia due to his diabetes and the use of IV insulin.
4. Infection: the patient is at risk for infection due to his compromised immune system and the presence of central lines.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: the patient is at risk for cardiac arrhythmias due to his underlying cardiac disease and the use of medications such as atenolol.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: the patient is at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding due to his underlying gastrointestinal disease and the use of anticoagulant medications.
7. Renal failure: the patient is at risk for renal failure due to his underlying kidney disease and the use of nephrotoxic medications.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current status, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and improve his outcomes.

   Assessment & Plan:  80y/o M with a PMH of CAD, HTN, PVD, COPD admitted
   to neurology service for new onset seizure now transferred to MICU
   following bradycardic arrest.
   .
   # Bradycardia
 Likely post ictal bradycardia, with some contributing
   medication effect from home atenolol.
   HR ranging 70-100 o/n
   EKG shows stable mild  QT prolongation (approx 420)
   Repeat EKG in am.
   - Hold atenolol
   # Seizure
 Etiology of new onset seizures remains unclear. Pt had some
   hypoglycemia in setting of being NPO, suggesting poor glycemic reserves
 hypoglycemia could lead to seizures. Also considerable atrophy on

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male admitted to the MICU for new onset seizure, bradycardic arrest, and altered mental status. The patient has a history of CAD, HTN, PVD, and COPD.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Fever: 101.5F, with a Tmax of 38.6C and Tcurrent of 37.1C
* Respiratory failure, acute, with a PCO2 of 70 mmHg
* Bradycardia, with a heart rate ranging from 70-100 beats per minute
* Hypoglycemia, with a glucose level of 129 mg/dL
* Altered mental status, with dementia, agitation, and disorientation
* Seizure disorder, with an unclear etiology
* Cardiac disease, with a history of CAD and dCHF
* COPD, with evidence of CO2 retention during the Code blue event

The patient has been receiving various medications, including:

* Vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam, and ciprofloxacin for empiric treatment of pneumonia
* Depakote for seizure control
* Zyprexa for agitation
* Hydralazine for hypertension
* Heparin sodium for prophylaxis of DVT

The patient's lab results show:

* WBC: 5.2-8.6 K/uL
* Hct: 36.6-36.7%
* Plt: 102-112 K/uL
* Cr: 0.5-0.7 mg/dL
* TropT: <0.01
* TCO2: 30-33 mmHg
* Glucose: 83-183 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 13.3/31.1/1.1, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 117/5/<0.01, ALT/AST: 9-17, Alk Phos/T Bili: 42/0.9

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CXR: Bilateral hemidiaphrams obscured, evolution of LLL patchy/flully area into an infiltrate, opacity with fluids given
* Head CT/MRI: Considerable atrophy, no acute changes, no evidence of tumor

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Sepsis, pneumonia, and aspiration pneumonia due to the patient's respiratory failure and altered mental status
* Cardiac arrhythmias, including bradycardia and QT prolongation, due to the patient's cardiac disease and medications
* Seizure disorder, with an unclear etiology
* Dementia, with a potential diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease or NPH
* COPD exacerbation, with evidence of CO2 retention during the Code blue event
* Hypoglycemia, with a potential diagnosis of diabetes
* Cardiac disease, with a history of CAD and dCHF

The patient's current plan is to continue empiric treatment of pneumonia, monitor for sepsis, and manage the patient's respiratory failure. The patient's medications will be continued as ordered, and the patient will be monitored for any changes in his condition.

   Assessment & Plan:  80y/o M with a PMH of CAD, HTN, PVD, COPD admitted
   to neurology service for new onset seizure now transferred to MICU
   following bradycardic arrest.
   .
   # Bradycardia
 Likely post ictal bradycardia, with some contributing
   medication effect from home atenolol.
   HR ranging 70-100 o/n
   EKG shows stable mild  QT prolongation (approx 420)
   Repeat EKG in am.
   - Hold atenolol
   # Seizure
 Etiology of new onset seizures remains unclear. Pt had some
   hypoglycemia in setting of being NPO, suggesting poor glycemic reserves
 hypoglycemia could lead to seizures. Also considerable atrophy on
   head CT/MRi but no acute changes, no evidence tumor. Degenerative
   changes could lead to seizure.
   EEG monitored y/d, read pending from neurology. On depakote, level
   therapeutic or NOT*************************
   Continue q4 neuro checks
    Continue depakote
   f/u EEG read
   -Dementia: Noted in records as mild however MRI suggests considerable
   disease
 Alzheimers vs NPH included in differential. Pt is
   occasionally agitated, but redirectable, oriented to person,
   disoriented to place/time. Neuro to follow.
    Continue zyprexa prn agitation with EKG monitoring for QT prolongation
   -restraints as needed
   # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure - PCO2 70 in the setting of
   bradycardia, low respiratory rate. Post extubation, blood gases/O2 sat
   have remained wnl, O2 dropped slightly, PCO2 increased slightly,  in am
   in setting of receiving sedatives for agitation and sleep.
   CXR this am continues to show blurring of hemidiaphrams bilaterally,
   unclear whether [**1-5**] to colonic obscuration, vs bilateral effusion, in
   pt with known dCHF but no infiltrate/opacity concerning for
   PNA/aspiration. Had cough y/d, none today,  unable thus far to collect
   sputum.

   - Repeat ABG if worsening picture.
   # CAD - unclear history of CAD
   -CXR/Echo suggests dCHF. Pt does not have sig edema/JVD/and is net
   fluid negative, hypertension does not appear to be related to fluid
   overload. EKG this am unchanged.
   - judicious use meds which may prolong QT
   .
   # COPD - Per report Pt has a history of COPD, had evidence of CO2
   retention during Code blue event however this was most likely secondary
   to decreased respiratory rate in setting of seizure vs bradycardic
   event
   -hypercarbia resolved
   -Continue to monitor MS, ABG with clinical changes.
   # FEN
 NPO currently, failed swallow eval. Consider soft NGT vs dopoff
   as pt pulls things out when agitated. If unable to keep in consider
   g-tube, if get to that point ,discuss with  family.
   All meds IV until NGT
   -Q4 glucose finger sticks.

d. Potential transition to floor.
